Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the percentage of money spent on health care through Medicare and Medicaid. The actual percentage is 30 cents on every dollar, not 46 cents as stated in the claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the stated percentage.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the money spent on health care through Medicare and Medicaid is the only federal spending on health care, without considering other federal health care programs.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the actual percentage of money spent on health care through Medicare and Medicaid is 30 cents on every dollar, not 46 cents.
Falters at times: The claim falters in accurately describing the statistic it refers to, as it inaccurately states that 46 cents on every dollar spent on health care is through Medicare and Medicaid.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the alternative explanation that federal money spent on health care programs other than Medicare and Medicaid contribute to the overall percentage of federal spending on health care.
